class.name: WindowsLookAndFeel
class.comment: These properties are not used directly, but are kept as
private members to avoid being GC'd.

ie. Take a look at RadioButtonBorder, etc...
When a desktop property change is detected, these classes must be
reinitialized in the defaults table to ensure the classes reference
the updated desktop property values (colors mostly)
Toggle flag for drawing the mnemonic state
Flag which indicates that the Win98/Win2k/WinME features
should be disabled.
********* Auditory Cue support methods and objects *********
Windows LayoutStyle. From:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/dnwue/html/ch14e.asp
class.javadoc:
Implements the Windows95/98/NT/2000 Look and Feel. UI classes not implemented specifically for Windows will default to those implemented in Basic.

Warning: Serialized objects of this class will not be compatible with future Swing releases. The current serialization support is appropriate for short term storage or RMI between applications running the same version of Swing. A future release of Swing will provide support for long term persistence. unattributed

A client property that can be used with any JComponent that will end up calling the LookAndFeel.getDisabledIcon method. This client property, when set to Boolean.TRUE, will cause getDisabledIcon to use an alternate algorithm for creating disabled icons to produce icons that appear similar to the native Windows file chooser
Base dialog units along the horizontal axis.
Base dialog units along the vertical axis.

method.name: initialize
method.comment: Set the flag which determines which version of Windows should
be rendered. This flag only need to be set once.
if version <= 4.0 then the classic LAF should be loaded.
Using the fonts set by the user can potentially cause
performance and compatibility issues, so allow this feature
to be switched off either at runtime or programmatically

class.javadoc:
Initialize the uiClassID to BasicComponentUI mapping. The JComponent classes define their own uiClassID constants (see AbstractComponent.getUIClassID). This table must map those constants to a BasicComponentUI class of the appropriate type.
BasicLookAndFeel#getDefaults

Load the SystemColors into the defaults table. The keys for SystemColor defaults are the same as the names of the public fields in SystemColor. If the table is being created on a native Windows platform we use the SystemColor values, otherwise we create color objects whose values match the defaults Windows95 colors.
Initialize the defaults table with the name of the ResourceBundle used for getting localized defaults.

method.comment: XXX - some of these doens't seem to be used
Set the flag which determines which version of Windows should
be rendered. This flag only need to be set once.
if version <= 4.0 then the classic LAF should be loaded.
The following four lines were commented out as part of bug 4991597
This code *is* correct, however it differs from WindowsXP and is, apparently
a Windows XP bug. Until Windows fixes this bug, we shall also exhibit the same

Object DisabledTextBackground = new XPColorValue(Part.EP_EDITTEXT, State.DISABLED, Prop.FILLCOLOR,

Put the desktop AA settings in the defaults. JComponent.setUI() retrieves this and makes it available as a client property on the JComponent. Use the same key name for both client property and UIDefaults. Also need to set up listeners for changes in these settings.
These desktop properties are not used directly, but are needed to
this key defines which of the various cues to render
Overridden from BasicL&F. This L&F should play all sounds
all the time. The infrastructure decides what to play.
This is disabled until sound bugs can be resolved.
used for Windows Classic. Windows XP will use colors

(checkbox uses RadioButtonBorder) is 2 all the way around too.

indicates that keyboard navigation won't skip disabled menu items

is 2 all the way around too.

method.name: initVistaComponentDefaults
method.comment: acceleratorSelectionForeground color is the same as acceleratorForeground
JPopupMenu has a bit of free space around menu items

class.javadoc: If we support loading of fonts from the desktop this will return a DesktopProperty representing the font. If the font can't be represented in the current encoding this will return null and turn off the use of system fonts.

method.name: getLazyValueDefaults
method.comment: For focus rectangle for cells and trees.

class.javadoc:
Sets the state of the hide mnemonic flag. This flag is used by the component UI delegates to determine if the mnemonic should be rendered. This method is a non operation if the underlying operating system does not support the mnemonic hiding feature.
hide true if mnemonics should be hidden
1.4

method.name: setMnemonicHidden
method.comment: Do not hide mnemonics if the UI defaults do not support this

class.javadoc:
Gets the state of the hide mnemonic flag. This only has meaning if this feature is supported by the underlying OS.
true if mnemonics are hidden, otherwise, false
#setMnemonicHidden
1.4

method.name: isMnemonicHidden
method.comment: Do not hide mnemonics if the UI defaults do not support this

class.javadoc:
Gets the state of the flag which indicates if the old Windows look and feel should be rendered. This flag is used by the component UI delegates as a hint to determine which style the component should be rendered.
true if Windows 95 and Windows NT 4 look and feel should be rendered
1.4

Invoked when the user attempts an invalid operation, such as pasting into an uneditable JTextField that has focus.

If the user has enabled visual error indication on the desktop, this method will flash the caption bar of the active window. The user can also set the property awt.visualbell=true to achieve the same results.

component Component the error occured in, may be null indicating the error condition is not directly associated with a Component. javax.swing.LookAndFeel#provideErrorFeedback
{@inheritDoc}

Returns an Action.

This Action contains the information and logic to render an auditory cue. The Object that is passed to this method contains the information needed to render the auditory cue. Normally, this Object is a String that points to a Toolkit desktopProperty. This desktopProperty is resolved by AWT and the Windows OS.

This Action's actionPerformed method is fired by the playSound method. an Action which knows how to render the auditory cue for one particular system or user activity #playSound(Action) 1.4

class.name: AudioAction
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.
class.javadoc: Pass the name String to the super constructor. This is used later to identify the Action and decide whether to play it or not. Store the resource String. It is used to get the audio resource. In this case, the resource is a Runnable supplied by Toolkit. This Runnable is effectively a pointer down into the Win32 OS that knows how to play the right sound. 1.4
We use the String as the name of the Action and as a pointer to the underlying OSes audio resource.

method.name: actionPerformed
method.comment: Runnable appears to block until completed playing, hence
start up another thread to handle playing.

class.name: LazyWindowsIcon
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.
class.javadoc: Gets an Icon from the native libraries if available, otherwise gets it from an image resource file.

class.name: ActiveWindowsIcon
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.
class.javadoc: Gets an Icon from the native libraries if available. A desktop property is used to trigger reloading the icon when needed.

method.name: ActiveWindowsIcon
method.comment: This desktop property is needed to trigger reloading the icon.
It is kept in member variable to avoid GC.

class.name: SkinIcon
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.
class.javadoc: Icon backed-up by XP Skin.
Draw the icon at the specified location. Icon implementations may use the Component argument to get properties useful for painting, e.g. the foreground or background color.

Returns the icon's width.
an int specifying the fixed width of the icon.

Returns the icon's height.
an int specifying the fixed height of the icon.

class.name: WindowsFontProperty
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.
class.javadoc: DesktopProperty for fonts. If a font with the name 'MS Sans Serif' is returned, it is mapped to 'Microsoft Sans Serif'.

method.name: configureValue
method.comment: 4950968: Workaround to mimic the way Windows maps the default
font size of 6 pts to the smallest available bitmap font size.
This happens mostly on Win 98/Me & NT.

class.name: WindowsFontSizeProperty
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.
class.javadoc: DesktopProperty for fonts that only gets sizes from the desktop, font name and style are passed into the constructor

class.name: XPValue
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.
class.javadoc: A value wrapper that actively retrieves values from xp or falls back to the classic value if not running XP styles.

class.name: XPBorderValue
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.

class.name: XPColorValue
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.

class.name: XPDLUValue
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.

class.name: TriggerDesktopProperty
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.

method.name: TriggerDesktopProperty
method.comment: This call adds a property change listener for the property,
which triggers a call to updateUI(). The value returned

method.name: updateUI
method.comment: Make sure property change listener is readded each time

class.name: FontDesktopProperty
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.

class.name: WindowsLayoutStyle
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.

method.name: getPreferredGap
method.comment: Between text labels and their associated controls (for
example, text boxes and list boxes): 3
'Text label beside a button 3 down from the top of
the button,' but I suspect that is an attempt to
enforce a baseline layout which will be handled
separately. In order to enforce this we would need
this API to return a more complicated type (Insets,

class.javadoc: Converts the dialog unit argument to pixels along the specified axis.
Calculates the dialog unit mapping.

1.6

method.name: getDisabledIcon
method.comment: if the component has a HI_RES_DISABLED_ICON_CLIENT_KEY
client property set to Boolean.TRUE, then use the new
hi res algorithm for creating the disabled icon (used
in particular by the WindowsFileChooserUI class)

class.name: RGBGrayFilter
class.comment: A constant that lets you specify null when using XP styles.

method.name: filterRGB
method.comment: find the average of red, green, and blue
